conclusion: Distance traveled equals the area under the velocity-time curve.
At t = 0 s, the initial velocity is 0 m/s.
The velocity increases in a curved pattern until t = 10 s.
At t = 10 s, the velocity reaches 20 m/s.
Approximate the area under the curve using estimates based on the shape shown.
Triangle area estimate: 0.5 × 10 s × 20 m/s = 100 m.
Rectangle area estimate: 10 s × 20 m/s = 200 m.
Average velocity is roughly equivalent to around 10-12 m/s over the 10-second interval.
The curve is concave up initially and then more linear as it approaches t = 10 s, suggesting average velocity is greater than 10 m/s.
Estimate average velocity to be approximately 11-12 m/s over the 10-second period.
Distance = Average velocity × Time = (11 to 12 m/s) × 10 s = 110 to 120 meters.
The distance fallen during the 0 to 10 seconds interval is greater than 100 meters.
